data:
## function_attributesData
> **attributesData**\<`T`\>(...`directives`): `object`


Returns an object with the attributes, style and class keys containing information derived from a list of directives.

  - The `attributes` value is a JSON representation of key/value attributes, excepted for the `class` and `style` attributes
  - The `classNames` value is an array of string representing the classes to be applied
  - The `style` value is a JSON representation of the styles to be applied

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T` *extends* `any`[]

The type of the directives array.

### Parameters

#### directives

...[`DirectivesAndOptParam`](../types#directivesandoptparam)\<`T`\>

List of directives to generate attributes from. Each parameter can be the directive or an array with the directive and its parameter

### Returns

`object`

JSON object with the `attributes`, `class` and `style` keys.

#### attributes

> **attributes**: [`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<`string`, `string`\>

#### classNames

> **classNames**: `string`[]

#### style

> **style**: [`Partial`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#partialtype)\<[`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<[`StyleKeyKebabCase`](../types#stylekeykebabcase) \| [`StyleKeyCustomProperty`](../types#stylekeycustomproperty), [`StyleValue`](../types#stylevalue)\>\>

## interface_AttributesDirectiveProps

Properties for configuring server-side rendering directives.

### Properties

#### attributes?

> `optional` **attributes**: [`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<`string`, [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`AttributeValue`](../types#attributevalue)\>\>


Attributes to be added to the provided node.

##### Remarks

The `style` attribute must be added separately.

***

#### classNames?

> `optional` **classNames**: [`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<`string`, [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<`boolean`\>\>


Class names to be added to an HTML element.

##### Remarks

Key-value pairs where keys are class names and values indicate whether the class should be added (true) or removed (false).

***

#### events?

> `optional` **events**: [`Partial`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#partialtype)\<\{ \}\>


Events to be attached to an HTML element.

##### Remarks

Key-value pairs where keys are event types and values are event handlers.
xw

***

#### styles?

> `optional` **styles**: [`Partial`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#partialtype)\<[`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<[`StyleKey`](../types#stylekey), [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`StyleValue`](../types#stylevalue)\>\>\>


Styles to be added to an HTML element.

##### Remarks

Key-value pairs where keys are CSS style properties and values are style values.

## function_bindDirective
> **bindDirective**\<`T`, `U`\>(`directive`, `directiveArg$`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\>


Binds the given directive to a store that provides its argument.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the directive argument.

#### U

`U` *extends* [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) = [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The type of the SSRHTMLElement, defaults to SSRHTMLElement.

### Parameters

#### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\>

The directive to bind to the element.

#### directiveArg$

[`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<`T`\>

The signal to subscribe to for directive updates.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\>

A directive that manages the lifecycle of the bound directive.

### Remarks

The returned directive can be used without argument, it will ignore any argument passed to it
and will call the provided directive with the content of the provided store as its argument,
calling its update method when the content of the store changes.

## function_bindDirectiveNoArg
> **bindDirectiveNoArg**\<`T`, `U`\>(`directive`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\>


Returns a directive that ignores any argument passed to it and calls the provided directive without any
argument.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the directive's argument.

#### U

`U` *extends* [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) = [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The type of the SSRHTMLElement, defaults to SSRHTMLElement.

### Parameters

#### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\>

The directive to bind without arguments.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\>

A new directive that does not require any arguments.

## constant_browserDirective
> `const` **browserDirective**: \<`T`, `U`\>(`directive`) => [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)\>


A higher-order directive function that conditionally applies a directive based on the environment.
If running in a browser environment, it applies the given directive to the node.
If not in a browser environment, it returns a no-op function.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the directive's argument.

#### U

`U` *extends* [`HTMLElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement)

The type of the HTML element the directive is applied to.

### Parameters

#### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\>

The directive to be conditionally applied.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)\>

- A directive that applies the given directive in a browser environment, or a no-op in a non-browser environment.

## constant_classDirective
> `const` **classDirective**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`ClassValue`\>


Directive that takes as an argument a string, array or object containing CSS classes to be put on the HTML element.
The class attribute is computed using the clsx library.

## function_createAttributesDirective
> **createAttributesDirective**\<`T`\>(`propsFn`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`\>


Creates a directive that binds attributes, styles, class names, and events to a DOM node.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T` = `void`

The type of the arguments passed to the directive.

### Parameters

#### propsFn

(`arg`) => [`AttributesDirectiveProps`](#attributesdirectiveprops)

A function that takes a readable signal of type `T` and returns an object containing
                 attributes, styles, class names, and events to bind to the node.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`\>

A directive function that can be used to bind the specified properties to a DOM node.

The returned directive function takes a DOM node and arguments of type `T`, and sets up the bindings
specified by the `propsFn` function. It returns an object with `update` and `destroy` methods:
- `update(args: T)`: Updates the arguments passed to the directive.
- `destroy()`: Cleans up all bindings and event listeners.

## function_createBrowserStoreArrayDirective
> **createBrowserStoreArrayDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. The store contains at any time the array of all the DOM elements on which the directive is
currently used.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on some DOM elements,
and the `elements$` property that is the store containing an array of all the elements on which the directive is currently
used.

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)\>

#### elements$

> **elements$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`HTMLElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement)[]\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createStoreArrayDirective](#createstorearraydirective), but the returned directive is only executed in a browser environment
and the type of the elements is HTMLElement instead of [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement).

If the directive is intended to be used on a single element element, it may be more appropriate to use
[createBrowserStoreDirective](#createbrowserstoredirective) instead.

## function_createBrowserStoreDirective
> **createBrowserStoreDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. When the directive is used on a DOM element, the store contains that DOM element.
When the directive is not used, the store contains null.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on one DOM element,
and the `element$` property that is the store containing the element on which the directive is currently used (or null
if the store is not currently used).

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)\>

#### element$

> **element$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`HTMLElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement) \| `null`\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createStoreDirective](#createstoredirective), but the returned directive is only executed in a browser environment
and the type of the element is HTMLElement instead of [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement).

If the directive is used on more than one element, an error is displayed in the console and the element is ignored.
If the directive is intended to be used on more than one element, please use [createStoreArrayDirective](#createstorearraydirective) instead.

## function_createConditionalBrowserStoreArrayDirective
> **createConditionalBrowserStoreArrayDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. The store contains at any time the array of all the DOM elements on which the directive is
currently used.

 The directive is applied depending on the value of its argument:
- `true` or `undefined`: Apply directive to the element.
- `false`: Do not apply apply directive to the element.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on some DOM elements,
and the `elements$` property that is the store containing an array of all the elements on which the directive is currently
used.

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`boolean` \| `undefined`, [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)\>

#### elements$

> **elements$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`HTMLElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement)[]\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createConditionalStoreArrayDirective](#createconditionalstorearraydirective), but the returned directive is only executed in a browser environment
and the type of the elements is HTMLElement instead of [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement).

If the directive is intended to be used on a single element element, it may be more appropriate to use
[createBrowserStoreDirective](#createbrowserstoredirective) instead.

## function_createConditionalStoreArrayDirective
> **createConditionalStoreArrayDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. The store contains at any time the array of all the DOM elements on which the directive is
currently used.

 The directive is applied depending on the value of its argument:
- `true` or `undefined`: Apply directive to the element.
- `false`: Do not apply apply directive to the element.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on some DOM elements,
and the `elements$` property that is the store containing an array of all the elements on which the directive is currently
used.

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`boolean` \| `undefined`\>

#### elements$

> **elements$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)[]\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createConditionalBrowserStoreArrayDirective](#createconditionalbrowserstorearraydirective), but the returned directive is also executed in a server environment
and the type of the elements is [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement) instead of HTMLElement.

If the directive is intended to be used on a single element element, it may be more appropriate to use
[createStoreDirective](#createstoredirective) instead.

## function_createStoreArrayDirective
> **createStoreArrayDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. The store contains at any time the array of all the DOM elements on which the directive is
currently used.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on some DOM elements,
and the `elements$` property that is the store containing an array of all the elements on which the directive is currently
used.

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)

#### elements$

> **elements$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)[]\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createBrowserStoreArrayDirective](#createbrowserstorearraydirective), but the returned directive is also executed in a server environment
and the type of the elements is [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement) instead of HTMLElement.

If the directive is intended to be used on a single element element, it may be more appropriate to use
[createStoreDirective](#createstoredirective) instead.

## function_createStoreDirective
> **createStoreDirective**(): `object`


Returns a directive and a store. When the directive is used on a DOM element, the store contains that DOM element.
When the directive is not used, the store contains null.

### Returns

`object`

An object with two properties: the `directive` property that is the directive to use on one DOM element,
and the `element$` property that is the store containing the element on which the directive is currently used (or null
if the store is not currently used).

#### directive

> **directive**: [`Directive`](../types#directive)

#### element$

> **element$**: [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<[`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) \| `null`\>

### Remarks

It is the same as [createBrowserStoreDirective](#createbrowserstoredirective), but the returned directive is also executed in a server environment
and the type of the element is [SSRHTMLElement](../types#ssrhtmlelement) instead of HTMLElement.

If the directive is used on more than one element, an error is displayed in the console and the element is ignored.
If the directive is intended to be used on more than one element, please use [createStoreArrayDirective](#createstorearraydirective) instead.

## function_directiveAttributes
> **directiveAttributes**\<`T`\>(...`directives`): [`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<`string`, `any`\>


Returns an object with the key/value attributes for JSX, derived from a list of directives.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T` *extends* `any`[]

â€” An array type representing the parameters for the directives.

### Parameters

#### directives

...[`DirectivesAndOptParam`](../types#directivesandoptparam)\<`T`\>

List of directives to generate attributes from. Each parameter can be the directive or an array with the directive and its parameter

### Returns

[`Record`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/utility-types.html#recordkeys-type)\<`string`, `any`\>

JSON object with key/value pairs to be applied on a JSX node.

## function_directiveSubscribe
> **directiveSubscribe**(`store`, `asyncUnsubscribe`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)


Returns a directive that subscribes to the given store while it is used on a DOM element,
and that unsubscribes from it when it is no longer used.

### Parameters

#### store

[`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<`any`\>

store on which there will be an active subscription while the returned directive is used.

#### asyncUnsubscribe

`boolean` = `true`

true if unsubscribing from the store should be done asynchronously (which is the default), and
false if it should be done synchronously when the directive is destroyed

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)

The resulting directive.

## function_directiveUpdate
> **directiveUpdate**\<`T`\>(`update`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`\>


Returns a directive that calls the provided function with the arguments passed to the directive
on initialization and each time they are updated.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the argument that the update function accepts.

### Parameters

#### update

(`arg`) => `void`

Function called with the directive argument when the directive is initialized and when its argument is updated.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`\>

The resulting directive.

## constant_isBrowserHTMLElement
> `const` **isBrowserHTMLElement**: (`element`) => `element is HTMLElement`


On a browser environment, returns true if the given element is an HTMLElement.
On a server environment, always returns false.

### Parameters

#### element

[`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The element to check.

### Returns

`element is HTMLElement`

true in a browser environment if the given element is an HTMLElement, otherwise false.

## function_mapDirectiveArg
> **mapDirectiveArg**\<`T`, `U`, `V`\>(`directive`, `fn`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `V`\>


Maps the argument of a directive to a new value using a provided function.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the original argument.

#### U

`U`

The type of the mapped argument.

#### V

`V` *extends* [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) = [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The type of the SSRHTMLElement, defaults to SSRHTMLElement.

### Parameters

#### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`U`, `V`\>

The original directive to be mapped.

#### fn

(`arg`) => `U`

The function to map the original argument to the new argument.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `V`\>

A new directive with the mapped argument.

## function_mergeDirectives
> **mergeDirectives**\<`T`, `U`\>(...`args`): [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\>


Merges multiple directives into a single directive that executes all of them when called.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of the argument passed to the directive.

#### U

`U` *extends* [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) = [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The type of the SSRHTMLElement, defaults to SSRHTMLElement.

### Parameters

#### args

...([`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\> \| [`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\>)[]

The directives to merge.

### Returns

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`, `U`\>

A new directive that applies all the given directives.

The returned directive has the following lifecycle methods:
- `update(arg)`: Updates all merged directives with the given argument.
- `destroy()`: Destroys all merged directives in reverse order.

### Remarks

All directives receive the same argument upon initialization and update.
Directives are created and updated in the same order as they appear in the arguments list,
they are destroyed in the reverse order.
All calls to the directives (to create, update and destroy them) are wrapped in a call to the
batch function of tansu

## function_multiDirective
> **multiDirective**\<`T`, `U`\>(`element`, `directives`): `object`


Applies multiple directives to a given SSRHTMLElement and provides methods to update or destroy them.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T` *extends* `any`[]

A tuple type representing the arguments for each directive.

#### U

`U` *extends* [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement) = [`SSRHTMLElement`](../types#ssrhtmlelement)

The type of the SSRHTMLElement, defaults to SSRHTMLElement.

### Parameters

#### element

`U`

The SSRHTMLElement to which the directives will be applied.

#### directives

[`DirectivesAndOptParam`](../types#directivesandoptparam)\<`T`, `U`\>

An array of directives and their optional parameters.

### Returns

`object`

An object containing:
- `update`: A function to update the directives with new parameters.
- `destroy`: A function to destroy all applied directives.

#### destroy

> **destroy**: () => `void`

##### Returns

`void`

#### update

> **update**: (`directives`) => `void`

##### Parameters

###### directives

([`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`void`, `U`\> \| [`DirectiveAndParam`](../types#directiveandparam)\<`any`, `U`\>)[]

##### Returns

`void`

## function_registrationArray
> **registrationArray**\<`T`\>(): [`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<`T`[]\> & `object`


Creates a registration array that allows elements to be added and removed.

### Type Parameters

#### T

`T`

The type of elements in the array.

### Returns

[`ReadableSignal`](https://amadeusitgroup.github.io/tansu/interfaces/ReadableSignal.html)\<`T`[]\> & `object`

An object that includes a readable signal of the array and a register function.

The returned object has the following properties:
- `register`: A function to add an element to the array. It takes an element of type `T` as a parameter and returns a function to remove the element from the array.

## constant_ssrAttributes
> `const` **ssrAttributes**: *typeof* [`directiveAttributes`](#directiveattributes)


Same as [directiveAttributes](#directiveattributes), but returns an empty object when run in a browser environement.

### Returns

JSON object with name/value for the attributes

## constant_useDirective
> `const` **useDirective**: \{(`directive`): `object`; \<`T`\>(`directive`, `args`): `object`; \}


The useDirective function.

Allows to attach a provided directive to the current react component.

#### Parameters

##### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)

#### Returns

`object`

##### ref

### Call Signature

> \<`T`\>(`directive`, `args`): `object`

#### Type Parameters

##### T

`T`

#### Parameters

##### directive

[`Directive`](../types#directive)\<`T`\>

##### args

`T`

#### Returns

`object`

##### ref

> **ref**: `RefCallback`\<[`HTMLElement`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement)\>

### Param

the directive

### Param

the args to pass to the directive

### Returns

the ref callback

## constant_useDirectives
> `const` **useDirectives**: \<`T`\>(...`directives`) => `object`


The useDirectives function.

Allows to attach multiple directives to the current react component.

### Type Parameters

`T` *extends* `any`[]

directives
